Award.AwardTitle: Conferences on Discrete Geometry and Algebraic Combinatorics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in two three-day conferences in the area of Discrete Geometry and Algebraic Combinatorics, held May 4-6, 2016 and in May 2017 in South Padre Island, TX. The conferences, eighth and ninth in a series, are devoted to a wide range of classical and modern problems in these active areas of mathematical research. The conferences bring together students and researchers in the region centered on the University of Texas - Rio Grande Valley. Due to the diverse composition of the student body, conference organizers expect to be able to attract a sizable fraction of attendees from among groups traditionally underrepresented in U.S. mathematics studies. The grant provides travel support for graduate students and early-career researchers, as well as non-local participants without other sources of support.

The two events represent the continuation of a successful series of conferences, the last of which was held in April 2015. The conference topics include: polytopes; packings, coverings, and tilings; rigidity and flexibility; geometric graph theory; topological combinatorics; incidence structures; lattices and discrete groups; geometric set partitioning and transversals; optimal configurations; spherical and Euclidean designs; distance sets; semidefinite programming in coding theory and discrete geometry; and strongly regular graphs. The conferences include an introduction of the research area through problems related to the topical areas and presentations of recent results by the leading experts in the field. More information is available at the conference web site:
www.utrgv.edu/discgeo

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Eighth Discrete Geometry and Algebraic Combinatorics Conference was organized on South Padre Island, TX, on May 4-6, 2016. 16 invited speakers gave their talks at the conference. Half of these speakers were junior researchers. The Ninth Discrete Geometry and Algebraic Combinatorics Conference was organized on South Padre Island, TX, on May 1-5, 2017. 27 talks were given by invited speakers at the South Padre Island Convention Centre with 7 talks by junior researchers. Both conferences were nationally and locally advertised.

11 faculty and around 15 students of the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley participated in conference activities in 2016. 12 faculty from the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley  and almost 20 students participated in the conference in 2017. Almost all students from the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley  participating in the conference are from underrepresented minorities.

This project allowed local students and invited researchers at the beginning stages of their career to be introduced to the current research in the areas of discrete mathematics and geometry and interact with established prominent mathematicians. On top of this, several new research projects were initiated by the talks delivered at the conferences and brought significant new results in combinatorics and discrete geometry.
